meta.description: Reimbursement coverage data for MedRep AI. Covers PM-JAY, CGHS, ESIC, Jan Aushadhi, and private insurance rules per drug category and per drug.

pmjay.coverage_model: Package-based reimbursement (HBP 2.0). Medicines bundled in package rates — no separate drug reimbursement.
pmjay.outpatient_medicines: NOT covered as standalone OPD reimbursement
pmjay.patient_payment: Zero at point of care for covered hospitalisations
pmjay.key_rule: Drugs used during approved hospitalisations are included in the package rate paid to the hospital

cghs.type: Employer-based scheme for Central Government employees, pensioners, and dependents
cghs.coverage_model: Free/subsidised medicines from CGHS wellness centres + cashless/reimbursed inpatient care
cghs.formulary_size: 1,447 generic + 622 branded items (MSO 2014); expanded in VMS 2023
cghs.dispensing_limit: Maximum 1 month supply per dispensing (3 months for travel abroad)
cghs.chronic_disease_supply: Available for diabetes, hypertension, cardiac conditions
cghs.key_rule: Medicines must be in CGHS formulary or life-saving list; non-formulary may be substituted

esic.type: Contributory social health insurance for covered establishment workers
esic.coverage_model: Comprehensive medical benefit through ESIS hospitals/dispensaries
esic.medicines_policy: Routine OPD and IPD medicines supplied per state formulary at no direct charge
esic.emergency_reimbursement: Allowed for emergency treatments at private hospitals (heart attack, haemorrhage, serious accidents)
esic.key_rule: All listed drugs routinely available at ESIC facilities; emergency private prescriptions may be reimbursed

jan_aushadhi.type: Government-run low-cost generic pharmacy network (NOT insurance)
jan_aushadhi.coverage_model: Patients pay out of pocket at heavily discounted generic prices
jan_aushadhi.key_rule: No reimbursement — but prices are 50-90% lower than brand-name equivalents

private_insurance.coverage_model: Primarily covers hospitalisation (inpatient) expenses. OPD medicines usually excluded unless OPD add-on purchased.
private_insurance.formulary_concept: Each insurer maintains own formulary; non-formulary drugs may require full out-of-pocket payment
private_insurance.pre_existing_disease: Maximum waiting period capped at 3 years under IRDAI norms
private_insurance.key_rule: Medicines during admitted hospital care are covered; chronic OPD prescriptions are generally NOT covered

pain_fever_antiinflammatory.pmjay: Included in hospitalisation packages (post-MI aspirin, perioperative analgesia). No OPD reimbursement.
pain_fever_antiinflammatory.cghs: Generic versions in CGHS formulary — supplied free at wellness centres for up to 1 month.
pain_fever_antiinflammatory.esic: Paracetamol: YES (injection, effervescent). Ibuprofen: YES (suspension). Diclofenac: YES (injection, suppositories, combos). Aceclofenac: NO. Aspirin: YES (soluble 350mg analgesic tablets; no 75mg cardio-dose in this schedule).
pain_fever_antiinflammatory.private: Covered during hospital admissions. Routine OPD prescriptions for fever/pain usually NOT reimbursed.
pain_fever_antiinflammatory.jan_aushadhi: Paracetamol 500mg ₹2.05/10s, Aspirin 75mg ₹2.50/14s — extremely affordable without insurance.
agent_questions: Are you covered by PM-JAY, CGHS, ESIC, or a private policy?
Is this for hospitalisation or OPD/self-purchase?
If private insurance: does your plan have OPD drug cover?

antibiotics.pmjay: Antibiotic costs bundled within hospitalisation package rates (pneumonia, sepsis, surgery).
antibiotics.cghs: Widely used antibiotics (amoxicillin, ceftriaxone, metronidazole) in CGHS formulary and life-saving lists.
antibiotics.esic: Amoxicillin: FDC ONLY (amox+clav combos, no plain tablet). Azithromycin: KIT ONLY. Cefixime: YES. Ceftriaxone: FDC ONLY (+sulbactam/+tazobactam). Metronidazole: NO. Levofloxacin: YES (500mg injection only). Doxycycline/Ciprofloxacin: not verified.
antibiotics.private: IV antibiotics during admission (ceftriaxone for sepsis) usually covered. OPD antibiotics generally NOT reimbursed.
agent_questions: Was the antibiotic part of a hospital admission or outpatient therapy?
Do you have access to a Jan Aushadhi Kendra nearby?

diabetes.pmjay: Covered during hospitalisations (MI, DKA, stroke). NOT for routine OPD diabetes prescriptions.
diabetes.cghs: Metformin (G18020), Glimepiride (G18041-42), Insulin (G18018-19, G18038-40) — all in formulary. Monthly supply via wellness centres.
diabetes.esic: Metformin: FDC ONLY (sitagliptin+met, vildagliptin+met; no plain tablet). Glimepiride: NO (ESIC uses glibenclamide/glipizide/gliclazide instead). Human Insulin: YES (40 IU/ml zinc, mixed 50/50, plus detemir and lispro).
diabetes.private: NOT covered for chronic OPD use. Covered during admissions (DKA, MI). Pre-existing diabetes: 3-year waiting period.
agent_questions: Is this about long-term monthly medicines or a recent hospitalisation?
Are you a CGHS/ESIC beneficiary (who get chronic drugs dispensed)?
Are you open to Jan Aushadhi generics to cut OPD costs?

cardiovascular.pmjay: Essential components of PM-JAY cardiac packages (ACS, PCI, stroke). In-hospital use included in package payments.
cardiovascular.cghs: Antihypertensives, statins, antiplatelets all in CGHS formulary/life-saving lists. Supplied free from wellness centres.
cardiovascular.esic: Amlodipine: FDC ONLY (perindopril+amlo, telmisartan+amlo, etc.; no standalone). Losartan: YES (25/50mg, +HCTZ). Telmisartan: FDC ONLY (tel+amlo only). Atorvastatin: YES (10/20mg). Rosuvastatin: YES (10/20mg). Clopidogrel: NO (ESIC lists ticlopidine instead).
cardiovascular.private: Inpatient cardiac episodes (MI, stenting, CABG) — drug costs covered. Long-term OPD BP/cholesterol NOT covered.
agent_questions: Is this about medicines used during a cardiac admission or ongoing home medication?
Do you have CGHS/ESIC benefits (chronic drug supply)?
Does your private plan include OPD/medicine coverage?

gastrointestinal.pmjay: PPIs and antiemetics during hospital stays (post-surgery GI protection, chemotherapy nausea) included in package tariff.
gastrointestinal.cghs: PPIs (omeprazole G17003, pantoprazole G17033) and ondansetron (G08049) in CGHS formulary. Dispensed at wellness centres.
gastrointestinal.esic: Pantoprazole: NO. Omeprazole: NO. ESIC uses rabeprazole and esomeprazole in PPI slot. Ondansetron: YES (4mg tablets).
gastrointestinal.private: Covered during hospitalised care. OPD prescriptions for gastritis/GERD rarely reimbursed.
agent_questions: Is this PPI for home OPD use or part of an admission?
Are you covered under any government scheme?
Would a cheaper generic from Jan Aushadhi be acceptable?
gastrointestinal.clinical_note: IMPORTANT: Use pantoprazole (not omeprazole) if patient is on clopidogrel — omeprazole reduces clopidogrel efficacy via CYP2C19 interaction.

respiratory.pmjay: Covered during PM-JAY admissions (status asthmaticus, COPD exacerbation). Not separately billed.
respiratory.cghs: Salbutamol (G25010), Budesonide (G25021), Montelukast (G25031) all in CGHS respiratory formulary. Supplied via wellness centres.
respiratory.esic: Salbutamol: YES (syrup, 100mcg inhaler, rotacaps/nebules, combos). Budesonide: YES (100mcg inhaler, +formoterol, +salbutamol respules). Montelukast: FDC ONLY (montelukast+levocetirizine and ebastine+montelukast tablets).
respiratory.private: Hospital respiratory care (nebulised drugs, IV steroids) covered. Chronic OPD inhaler prescriptions seldom reimbursed.
agent_questions: Is this about emergency hospitalisation costs or month-to-month inhaler expense?
Do you have ESIC coverage or retail private insurance?
Is there a Jan Aushadhi Kendra nearby for cheaper inhalers?
